study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether modifying soy protein isolate (SPI) with pulsed electric field (PEF) and pH shifting could improve lutein encapsulation efficiency, loading capacity, and stability.
results_summary: The combined PEF and pH shifting treatment significantly improved lutein encapsulation efficiency (from 54% to 77%) and loading capacity (by 41%) in SPI nanoparticles, resulting in smaller, more homogeneous particles with enhanced solubility and stability.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)
effective_dosage: Mass ratio of SPI to lutein was 25:1

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of TGF-β1 in regulating SPARC expression in human ovarian granulosa-lutein (hGL) cells and its potential involvement in the pathogenesis of OHSS.
results_summary: TGF-β1 upregulated SPARC expression in hGL cells via SMAD3 and Slug, and SPARC knockdown reduced TGF-β1-stimulated VEGF and aromatase expression, markers of OHSS. SPARC was also upregulated in OHSS rat ovaries and follicular fluid of OHSS patients.
population_specificity: Human granulosa-lutein (hGL) cells from IVF patients and OHSS rat models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate a lutein-loaded nanocarrier (LNCs) to improve lutein's bioavailability and assess its protective effects against oxidative stress and angiogenesis in diabetic retinopathy (DR) using ARPE-19 cells.
results_summary: LNCs showed higher cellular uptake, reduced oxidative stress markers, restored antioxidant enzymes, and normalized angiogenic and endoplasmic reticulum stress markers in ARPE-19 cells under stress conditions. The nanocarrier effectively protected retinal cells from hyperglycemia-mediated damage.
population_specificity: ARPE-19 cells (human retinal pigment epithelial cell line) under normal and stress conditions (H2O2-induced oxidative stress and CoCl2-induced hypoxia).
effective_dosage: Up to 20 μM (concentration tested for cell viability).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the extent of lutein degradation under varying temperature, pH, and duration conditions, and its impact on functional stability.
results_summary: Lutein degradation increased significantly at lower pH, higher temperatures, and longer exposure durations, but its structure and bioactivity could be retained under higher pH (7-8) and lower temperatures (40-50°C) for short periods (<1 h).
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the function and mechanism of lutein administration on chronic ethanol-induced liver and intestinal barrier damage in rats.
results_summary: Lutein interventions prevented alcohol-induced liver tissue damage, oxidative stress, and inflammation, while also upregulating intestinal barrier proteins Claudin-1 and Occludin. The study found that lutein improved chronic alcoholic liver injury and intestinal barrier dysfunction.
population_specificity: Rats (70 rats divided into seven groups)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether resveratrol protects rat ovarian granulosa-lutein cells from oxidative stress-induced injury and apoptosis via the SIRT1/Nrf2/ARE signaling pathway.
results_summary: Resveratrol ameliorated H2O2-induced cell injury and apoptosis, reduced oxidative stress markers, and activated the SIRT1/Nrf2/ARE pathway, but its protective effects were nullified when Nrf2 was inhibited.
population_specificity: Ovarian granulosa-lutein cells extracted from 3-week-old female Sprague-Dawley rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of lutein on intestinal health, growth performance, and the underlying anti-inflammatory mechanism in broilers.
results_summary: Lutein supplementation (40 mg/kg) showed trends in improving feed intake and growth performance, reduced proinflammatory cytokines (IL-1β, IL-6), and increased anti-inflammatory cytokines (IL-4, IL-10) in broilers. It also improved jejunal villi height and reduced damage, with effects mediated via the TLR4/MyD88 pathway.
population_specificity: Male yellow-feathered broilers (1-day old)
effective_dosage: 20 mg/kg and 40 mg/kg of lutein in diet

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of lutein on the adhesion, invasiveness, and metastasis of human prostate cancer PC-3M cells and its underlying mechanism.
results_summary: Lutein significantly reduced cell adhesion, pseudopodia formation, expressions of metastasis-related proteins (paxillin, MMP-2, MMP-9, N-cadherin, vimentin), and inhibited cell invasion and migration. It also upregulated TIMP-1 and E-cadherin, suggesting suppression of epithelial-mesenchymal transition.
population_specificity: Human prostate cancer PC-3M cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how lutein affects the expression of pyroptosis-related genes in senescent human retinal pigment epithelial cells (ARPE-19) exposed to oxidative stress.
results_summary: Lutein modulated the expression of pyroptosis-related genes (TXNIP, CXCL8, BAX, CASP1) in ARPE-19 cells, suggesting a potential role in preventing pyroptosis pathway activation under oxidative stress. The findings were statistically significant and supported by both microarray and RT-qPCR validation.
population_specificity: Senescent human retinal pigment epithelial cell line (ARPE-19).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the role of IL-1 in regulating ovarian follicle function, specifically its impact on prostaglandin E2 (PGE2) production and COX-2 expression in human granulosa cells.
results_summary: The study found that IL-1α and IL-1β increased PGE2 production by upregulating COX-2 expression via NF-κB/p65 and ERK1/2 signaling pathways in human granulosa cells. The nuclear translocation of p65 and its transcriptional regulation of COX-2 were key mechanisms identified.
population_specificity: Primary human granulosa-lutein (hGL) cells and immortalized human granulosa-like tumor cell line (KGN).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether lutein-loaded nanoparticles could reverse ASD-like behaviors and associated oxidative stress and apoptosis in female rats prenatally exposed to valproic acid.
results_summary: Lutein-loaded nanoparticles reversed sociability deficits, social memory deficits, anxiety-like behaviors, and repetitive behaviors induced by VPA, while also restoring oxidative stress indicators and apoptosis biomarkers in the hippocampus.
population_specificity: Female Wistar rat offspring prenatally exposed to valproic acid (VPA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether lutein could mitigate glutamate-induced oxidative stress, inflammation, iron metabolism dysregulation, and lipid peroxidation in neuroblastoma cells.
results_summary: Lutein attenuated glutamate-induced increases in ROS, inflammation, iron accumulation, and lipid peroxidation in SH-SY5Y cells, suggesting potential neuroprotective benefits.
population_specificity: SH-SY5Y neuroblastoma cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of oral intake of Lutein and zeaxanthin (L/Z) on circulating total cholesterol, LDL-C, and HDL-C levels.
results_summary: L/Z supplementation had no significant effect on total cholesterol or LDL-C levels but significantly increased HDL-C levels in older adults.
population_specificity: Older adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the bioaccessibility and intestinal uptake of lutein (LT) when encapsulated in zein-alginate-phosphatidylcholine nanoparticles (LTZAP NPs) compared to dietary absorption.
results_summary: The study found that LTZAP NPs significantly enhanced the bioaccessibility, cellular uptake, and basolateral secretion of lutein compared to micellar carotenoids (dietary absorption). Co-treatment with LYZAP + LTZAP NPs showed better carotenoid release than individual treatments at intestinal pH.
population_specificity: Human intestinal Caco-2 cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether HB-EGF could upregulate StAR expression and progesterone production in human granulosa-lutein cells, similar to other EGFR ligands.
results_summary: HB-EGF treatment increased StAR expression and progesterone production in both KGN and hGL cells, mediated by EGFR, HER4, and the ERK1/2 signaling pathway, without affecting other steroidogenesis-related enzymes.
population_specificity: Human granulosa-lutein cells from patients undergoing in vitro fertilization and a steroidogenic ovarian granulosa-like tumor cell line (KGN).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a cost-effective, efficient magnetic nanoparticle-based method for harvesting microalgae biomass, specifically Chlorella sorokiniana, for commercial-scale biorefining.
results_summary: The study achieved >99% harvesting efficiency using magnetite nanoparticles (MNPs) under optimal conditions (pH 3, 200 mg/L MNPs, 450 rpm agitation). MNPs were successfully recovered and reused for up to 5 cycles without losing reactivity.
population_specificity: Microalgae cultures (Chlorella sorokiniana Kh12 and Tu5).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding LH to FSH could recover cAMP and progesterone production in human primary granulosa lutein cells (hGLCs) from sub/poor-responder women undergoing ovarian stimulation during ART.
results_summary: The study found that hGLCs from normo-responders were more sensitive to FSH than those from sub/poor-responders, but adding LH to FSH significantly improved cAMP and progesterone levels in all groups, bridging the gap between normo- and sub/poor-responders. No genetic differences in FSHR were found between groups.
population_specificity: Women undergoing ovarian stimulation during assisted reproductive technology (ART), stratified into normo-, sub-, and poor-responders.
study_duration: Measurements taken after 3 hours (cAMP) and 24 hours (progesterone).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether AREG and TGF-β1 regulate VE-cadherin expression and subsequent angiogenesis in human granulosa-lutein (hGL) cells during corpus luteum formation.
results_summary: AREG promoted microvascular-like formation in hGL cells by upregulating VE-cadherin via the EGFR-ERK1/2 pathway, while TGF-β1 suppressed it by downregulating VE-cadherin via the ALK5-SMAD2/3/4 pathway.
population_specificity: Human granulosa-lutein (hGL) cells

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate lutein's role in attenuating methylglyoxal (MGO)-induced oxidative damage and apoptosis in PC12 cells and explore the underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: Lutein significantly reduced reactive oxygen species (ROS) and oxidative stress in MGO-induced PC12 cells, enhanced antioxidant enzyme activity, decreased apoptosis and mitochondrial damage, and modulated the PI3K/Akt signaling pathway.
population_specificity: PC12 cells (a rat adrenal pheochromocytoma cell line)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility of using melatonin (MT) to increase lutein yield in a novel microalgae strain (Acutodesmus sp. HLGY) and explore the role of MT in promoting lutein biosynthesis.
results_summary: Under 7.5 μM MT treatment, lutein content and productivity increased by 1.53 times compared to the control. MT also upregulated key lutein synthesis- and antioxidant enzyme-related genes while suppressing carbohydrate, protein, ROS, and lipid levels, and increasing ethylene and γ-aminobutyric acid contents.
population_specificity: Microalgae strain (Acutodesmus sp. HLGY) isolated from Yajiageng Red Rock Beach.

study_goal: The study aimed to assess the concentrations of phytoene (PT) and phytofluene (PTF) in serum and faeces from healthy Spanish normolipemic subjects and evaluate the effect of a fruit and vegetable dietary intervention on these carotenoids.
results_summary: PT showed higher concentrations than PTF in serum, faeces, and dietary intake. The dietary intervention did not significantly alter PT and PTF intake or serum concentrations but reduced faecal concentrations in the fruit group.
population_specificity: Healthy Spanish normolipemic subjects (n = 101, 45-65 years).
effective_dosage: Median dietary intake was 2.4 mg/p/day for PT and 0.6 mg/p/day for PTF.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the protective effects of Sulforaphane (SFN) against oxidative stress in granulosa-lutein cells (GLCs) by activating the AMPK/AKT/NRF2 pathway.
results_summary: SFN reduced intracellular ROS and apoptosis levels in GLCs exposed to H2O2-induced oxidative stress and increased the expression of AMPK, AKT, and NRF2 genes and proteins. The findings suggest SFN may protect GLCs from oxidative damage.
population_specificity: Granulosa-lutein cells obtained from individuals undergoing intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI) cycles.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether oxidized lutein products (LOPs) could serve as a novel antiobesity treatment by inhibiting pancreatic lipase and modulating PPAR-γ activity.
results_summary: Total LOPs and LOP6 significantly inhibited pancreatic lipase activity, with LOP6 showing better binding affinity for PPAR-γ and pancreatic lipase than orlistat. Histological data confirmed antiobesity effects, including reduced hepatocyte degeneration and inflammatory cell invasion in adipose tissue.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and histological evaluation, likely animal models).
effective_dosage: Not specified (three doses of total LOPs mentioned, but exact amounts not provided).
study_duration: 10 days (for LOP formation under sunlight exposure).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the protective mechanism of lutein on adipogenesis-mediated inflammation in vitro, focusing on its potential role in managing obesity-related inflammation.
results_summary: Lutein effectively reduced protein levels of key inflammatory markers (NF-κB, IL-1β, MCP-1, TNF-α) in differentiated adipocytes and adipogenesis-induced macrophages, suggesting it regulates the NF-κB signaling pathway to mitigate inflammation.
population_specificity: RAW264.7 macrophages cultured in adipocyte-conditioned medium (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the relationship between lutein supplementation and age-related macular degeneration (AMD), focusing on its effects on macular pigment optical density (MPOD) and circulating lutein levels.
results_summary: The study found that lutein supplementation significantly increased MPOD in AMD patients, particularly at higher doses (20 mg/d) and longer durations (>6 months), but did not affect circulating lutein levels. The results suggest potential benefits for AMD patients with specific dosing regimens.
population_specificity: AMD patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how selenium (Se), sulfur (S), and methyl jasmonate (MeJA) treatments affect lutein accumulation in kale sprouts.
results_summary: The study found that lutein accumulation was highest after 7 days of treatment with S 120 mg/L (178% increase in Red Russian kale) and Se 40 mg/L (199% increase in Dwarf Green kale). MeJA treatment did not significantly affect lutein levels but increased kaempferol and quercetin in both varieties.
population_specificity: Red Russian and Dwarf Green kale sprouts grown in controlled chamber conditions.
study_duration: 7 days of germination with harvests every 24 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether soy protein isolate (SPI) treated with high-pressure homogenization (HPH) could effectively serve as a nanocarrier for lutein, improving its stability and antioxidant activity.
results_summary: The study found that SPI-lutein nanocomplexes achieved the highest encapsulation efficiency (92.85%) and load amount (2.32 mg/mL) at 60 MPa HPH, with improved antioxidant activity (DPPH and hydroxyl-antioxidant activities increased significantly). The combination of SPI and lutein enhanced lutein stability and altered protein secondary structure.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the photosynthetic performance and stress tolerance of lutein-deficient mutant (lut2) and wild-type Arabidopsis thaliana under low temperature and high light conditions.
results_summary: The study found that lut2 plants exhibited lower electrolyte leakage, lower excitation pressure, and higher actual photochemical efficiency of PSII compared to wild-type plants under combined stress. The results suggest that lutein deficiency may enhance stress tolerance through alternative photoprotective mechanisms, such as cyclic electron flow and PSI-dependent energy quenching.
population_specificity: Arabidopsis thaliana (plant model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and characterize a mutant strain of Chromochloris zofingiensis (Cz-pkg) for enhanced lutein production and to study its potential as a commercial source.
results_summary: The mutant strain Cz-pkg showed significantly higher lutein accumulation (31.93 ± 1.91 mg L-1) and productivity (10.57 ± 0.73 mg L-1 day-1) compared to its mother strain, with lutein content (7.73 ± 0.52 mg g-1 of dry weight) surpassing marigold flower, the common commercial source. Transcriptomic analysis suggested PKG may regulate photosynthetic pigment metabolism.
population_specificity: Microalgae (Chromochloris zofingiensis mutant strain Cz-pkg)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of lutein and zeaxanthin in human health, focusing on their metabolism, bioavailability, and protective effects against oxidative stress and eye diseases.
results_summary: The study found that lutein and zeaxanthin are crucial for eye health, particularly in delaying the progression of age-related macular degeneration (AMD) and cataracts, due to their antioxidant properties and accumulation in the retina. Consuming xanthophyll-rich foods was recommended to support these benefits.
population_specificity: Adults (general population, no specific subgroup mentioned).
effective_dosage: Recommended daily intake of lutein is approximately 10.0 mg and zeaxanthin is 2 mg.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether RGO-TiO2 nanoparticles could enhance light utilization and lutein accumulation in Chlorella sorokiniana F31.
results_summary: The study found that RGO-TiO2 nanoparticles significantly improved lutein production, content, and productivity compared to TiO2 nanoparticles and the control group, achieving a maximum lutein content of 15.55 mg/g and production of 77.2 mg/L.
population_specificity: Chlorella sorokiniana F31 (microalgae)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of GDF-11 in regulating ovarian steroidogenesis, particularly its effect on StAR expression in human granulosa-lutein (hGL) cells.
results_summary: GDF-11 downregulated StAR expression in hGL cells without affecting P450scc or 3β-HSD. Unlike GDF-8, GDF-11 levels did not differ between non-PCOS and PCOS patients.
population_specificity: Human granulosa-lutein (hGL) cells from patients undergoing IVF treatment, including 36 non-PCOS and 36 PCOS patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a proprietary lutein, zeaxanthin, and rosemary formulation in protecting against UV-induced skin dehydration.
results_summary: The formulation significantly improved skin hydration, elasticity, and collagen type 1 gene expression compared to placebo, with all subjective parameters reaching statistical significance (P<0.05). It also enhanced serum biochemical markers related to skin moisturizing activity.
population_specificity: 48 male Swiss albino mice aged 8–12 weeks.
effective_dosage: Low and high doses of 2 different test substances (specific amounts not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of antioxidants (celastrol and melatonin) on SIRT1, SIRT6, and SIRT7 gene expression and cell survival in human granulosa-lutein (hGL) cells under oxidative stress conditions.
results_summary: Melatonin and celastrol improved hGL cell survival under oxidative stress, with melatonin inducing SIRT1, SIRT6, and SIRT7 gene expression, while celastrol only induced SIRT7. The response was unaffected by oxidative stress inducers.
population_specificity: Cultured human granulosa-lutein (hGL) cells

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the protective mechanism of lutein on hyperglycemia-induced endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress in ARPE-19 cells.
results_summary: Lutein pretreatment blocked glucose-mediated reduction in BiP expression, activated IRE1-XBP1, ATF6, and ATF4 pathways, and upregulated downstream UPR genes, demonstrating protection against hyperglycemia-induced ER stress.
population_specificity: ARPE-19 cells (a human retinal pigment epithelial cell line)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether lutein alone could protect retinal photoreceptors and improve visual function in a mouse model of retinitis pigmentosa.
results_summary: Lutein at 200 mg/kg promoted photoreceptor survival, increased rhodopsin and opsin expression, improved visual behavior, acuity, and retinal electroretinogram responses, and reduced reactive gliosis in Müller cells.
population_specificity: Pde6brd10 model mice with retinal photoreceptor degeneration.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of lutein in pancreatic adenocarcinoma (PDAC) progression and its potential mechanisms, particularly its interaction with BAG3 and cholesterol homeostasis.
results_summary: Lutein suppressed proliferation, migration, and invasion of PANC-1 cells by targeting BAG3 and modulating cholesterol homeostasis, suggesting potential therapeutic benefits for PDAC. Overexpression of BAG3 reversed lutein's inhibitory effects.
population_specificity: PANC-1 cells (a pancreatic adenocarcinoma cell line)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether lutein, combined with PVA in eye drops, could effectively reduce inflammation and treat dry eye syndrome (DES) in a mouse model.
results_summary: The study found that lutein/PVA eye drops reduced inflammatory gene expression (IL-1β, IL-6, TNF-α) in human corneal epithelial cells and improved corneal repair, tear secretion, and goblet cell count in DES mice.
population_specificity: Benzalkonium chloride-induced DES mouse model and human corneal epithelial cells (HCE-2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of lutein as a therapeutic agent against neurodegenerative diseases (NDDs) by examining its neuroprotective and neuroplasticity-enhancing properties.
results_summary: Lutein demonstrated neuroprotective effects against various NDDs, including Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, Huntington's, and cerebral ischemia, by reducing free radicals, strengthening antioxidant systems, suppressing mitochondrial aberrations, and improving neuroplasticity through increased neurogenesis markers. It also showed immunomodulatory activity, preventing neuroinflammation and rescuing memory defects.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and in vivo studies, but no human population details provided).

study_goal: The researchers described a rare case of theca lutein cysts with maternal virilization that failed to regress postpartum, necessitating surgical intervention.
results_summary: The study reported a rare case of persistent theca lutein cysts causing maternal virilization, which did not resolve spontaneously and required surgical treatment due to adnexal torsion.
population_specificity: Pregnant patient with theca lutein cysts and subsequent maternal virilization.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of lutein in mitigating oxidative and nitrosative stress, particularly in the context of long COVID, mRNA vaccination injury syndromes, and chronic illnesses like cardiovascular and neurodegenerative diseases.
results_summary: The study found that lutein acts as a potent antioxidant and anti-inflammatory agent, protecting against oxidative and nitrosative stress, improving cardiometabolic and organ health, and potentially inhibiting spike protein-induced inflammation. It also suggested synergy with other natural compounds for spike protein detoxification.
population_specificity: General human population, with specific relevance to individuals with chronic illnesses, long COVID, or mRNA vaccination injury syndromes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether pistachio consumption, as a source of lutein, could increase macular pigment optical density (MPOD) in adults with low baseline lutein/zeaxanthin intake.
results_summary: Pistachio consumption significantly increased MPOD at all retinal eccentricities within 6 weeks, with effects maintained at 12 weeks. Serum lutein concentration mirrored MPOD changes, while serum cis-lutein and zeaxanthin remained unchanged.
population_specificity: Middle-aged to older healthy adults with habitually low lutein/zeaxanthin intake and low baseline MPOD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of Lutein as an antioxidant therapy for preventing and managing cataracts by mitigating oxidative stress in ocular tissues.
results_summary: The review suggests Lutein may help prevent cataract formation by reducing oxidative damage to lens proteins and lipids, but current evidence is sparse, and further clinical studies are needed to confirm its efficacy.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion on cataract formation and antioxidant therapies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of macular pigment optical density (MPOD) as a measurable, modifiable clinical biomarker, particularly in assessing the eye's antioxidant capacity in oxidative damage and retinal ischemia.
results_summary: Elevated MPOD levels, influenced by carotenoid intake or supplementation, offer robust protection against age-related macular degeneration (AMD) and are associated with retinal defense mechanisms against oxidative stress and excessive light exposure. MPOD measurement shows promise for early disease detection and monitoring in various ocular conditions.
population_specificity: General population, with emphasis on elderly individuals at risk for age-related ocular diseases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize interindividual variability in adipose tissue concentrations of lutein and zeaxanthin and identify genetic polymorphisms associated with these concentrations.
results_summary: The study found mean lutein and zeaxanthin concentrations in adipose tissue and identified associations between specific SNPs and these concentrations, suggesting genetic factors may influence storage.
population_specificity: 42 healthy adult males

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the neuroprotective potential of carotenoids, including lutein, in preventing and alleviating Alzheimer's disease symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that carotenoids, including lutein, can cross the blood-brain barrier, scavenge free radicals, and help prevent neurodegeneration and cognitive impairment in Alzheimer's disease. A diet rich in carotenoids is recommended to reduce the risk of cognitive decline.
population_specificity: Individuals with or at risk of Alzheimer's disease and mild cognitive impairment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the pathophysiology of CKD and explore the potential of plant-dominant dietary patterns, including possible roles of nutrients like Lutein, in preventing and managing CKD.
results_summary: The abstract does not specifically mention Lutein's effects but discusses the broader efficacy of plant-dominant diets in CKD management and outlines novel regeneration strategies targeting IL-11 inhibition.
population_specificity: Adults, particularly older adults, with or at risk of chronic kidney disease (CKD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Lutein, as part of enriched eggs, could improve microvascular function, oxidative stress, and inflammatory mediators in patients after acute coronary syndrome (ACS).
results_summary: The study found that Lutein, combined with other nutrients in enriched eggs, improved microvascular reactivity (PORH and ACh ID) and increased serum levels of key nutrients without adverse effects on oxidative stress.
population_specificity: Patients with acute coronary syndrome (ACS), mean age ~57 years.
effective_dosage: 0.330 mg of lutein daily (consumed via three enriched eggs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the relationship between Macular Pigment Optical Density (MPOD) values (indicative of lutein and zeaxanthin accumulation) and cognitive and visual function in children.
results_summary: The study found that lutein and zeaxanthin accumulation plays an important role in childhood development, with cognitive function showing a stronger correlation with MPOD values than visual function. However, the relationship with visual function remains unclear, requiring further research.
population_specificity: Children aged 0 to 18 years, including premature infants up to 12-year-olds.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the MIND diet was a stronger predictor of carotenoid intake, particularly lutein, compared to other dietary patterns.
results_summary: The study found that the MIND diet was more strongly associated with higher intake of lutein and zeaxanthin, β-carotene, α-carotene, and β-cryptoxanthin compared to other dietary indices, suggesting a greater emphasis on carotenoid-rich foods.
population_specificity: 396 adults aged 19-82 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the influence of lutein and other carotenoids on bone health, including antiosteoporotic and bone-building effects.
results_summary: The abstract indicates that lutein and other carotenoids may have potential antiosteoporotic and bone-supporting effects, based on in vitro experiments, animal models, and clinical studies, but specific results for lutein are not detailed.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of various studies, including in vitro, animal models, and humans).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the therapeutic potential of lutein and zeaxanthin in improving ocular health and other physiological benefits, as well as challenges in optimizing their delivery.
results_summary: The study found that lutein and zeaxanthin enhance ocular health by protecting against oxidative damage, macular degeneration, and other eye diseases, while also improving cognitive function and cardiovascular health. However, their bioavailability is low, prompting research into improved delivery methods like lipid nano-emulsions.
population_specificity: Aging population and individuals with eye health concerns (not further specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the molecular mechanisms and potential anti-prostate cancer effects of lutein and other phytochemicals.
results_summary: The abstract suggests lutein exerts anti-prostate cancer effects by inhibiting proliferation, metastasis, cell cycle progression, and apoptosis pathways, but does not provide specific data on its efficacy.
population_specificity: Prostate cancer cells (in vitro or in vivo context not specified).

study_goal: The study aimed to evaluate the safety, pharmacokinetics, and effects of β-cryptoxanthin supplementation on various health parameters in healthy women.
results_summary: The study found that β-cryptoxanthin supplementation (3 and 6 mg/day) was safe and well tolerated, with higher plasma concentrations in the 6 mg/day group. No impact on other carotenoids was observed.
population_specificity: 90 healthy Asian women aged 21-35 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether lutein/zeaxanthin supplementation could slow the progression of age-related macular degeneration (AMD) and serve as a safer alternative to beta-carotene in the AREDS formula.
results_summary: The study found that lutein/zeaxanthin may slightly reduce the risk of progression to late AMD, neovascular AMD, and geographic atrophy, though the evidence was of low certainty. Exploratory analyses suggested it could be a suitable replacement for beta-carotene in the AREDS formula, with no significant adverse effects noted.
population_specificity: People aged 65-75 years with early or intermediate AMD, predominantly women (56%).
study_duration: Ranged from six months to five years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a supplement containing lutein, astaxanthin, and zeaxanthin could prevent impairment of eye-hand coordination and smooth-pursuit eye movement caused by VDT operation.
results_summary: The active group showed significantly improved eye-hand coordination after eight weeks of supplementation, but no clear improvement in smooth-pursuit eye movements. MPOD levels also increased significantly in the active group.
population_specificity: Healthy subjects who regularly worked with visual display terminals (VDTs).
effective_dosage: 10 mg lutein (combined with 6 mg astaxanthin and 2 mg zeaxanthin) once daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary supplementation with lutein-enriched hen eggs could promote anti-inflammatory effects compared to regular hen eggs.
results_summary: The study found decreased serum levels of pro-inflammatory IL-17A and increased nNOS expression in the lutein-enriched group, suggesting a shift toward anti-inflammatory conditions. Metabolite alterations in the control group via COX pathways further supported these findings.
population_specificity: 34 participants (specific demographics not detailed).
effective_dosage: 3 hard-boiled hen eggs per day (lutein-enriched vs. regular).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the structural and optical properties of carotenoids, including Lutein, and explore advances in Raman spectroscopy for identifying carotenoids in biological environments.
results_summary: The abstract highlights the clinical importance of carotenoid analysis and reviews Raman spectroscopy applications in nutritional analysis, optometry, and serology, but does not specify Lutein's effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of carotenoids in biological environments).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the Veggie Meter could detect changes in skin carotenoid levels (including lutein) in response to increased carotenoid intake and compare these changes to plasma carotenoid levels.
results_summary: The study found that skin carotenoid scores, including lutein, significantly increased in response to higher carotenoid intake, with a 42% change in skin carotenoids and a 61% change in plasma carotenoids in the high-dose group over 6 weeks.
population_specificity: 162 participants from four US racial/ethnic groups (25% Black, 25% Asian, 27% non-Hispanic White, 23% Hispanic).
effective_dosage: High-dose group received 8 mg total carotenoids/day (355 mL orange-carrot juice/day), moderate-dose group received 4 mg total carotenoids/day (177 mL orange-carrot juice/day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between lutein and zeaxanthin status and musculoskeletal health indices, as well as incident frailty, in adults aged ≥50 years.
results_summary: Higher plasma lutein and zeaxanthin concentrations were associated with improved gait speed, reduced TUG time, and lower odds of progressing to frailty, but not with grip strength or sarcopenia. Baseline concentrations were linked to reduced frailty risk over ~8 years but did not predict longitudinal changes in musculoskeletal outcomes.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling adults aged ≥50 years in the Irish Longitudinal Study on Ageing (TILDA).
study_duration: Follow-up periods ranged from 4 to 8 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Lutein and zeaxanthin supplementation improves cognitive function, academic achievement, and macular pigment optical density in preadolescent children.
results_summary: The study is ongoing, so no results are reported in the abstract. It hypothesizes that Lutein + zeaxanthin supplementation will enhance cognition and academic achievement, mediated by increases in macular carotenoids.
population_specificity: Preadolescent children aged 8-10 years (N = 288).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of lutein, among other dietary supplements, in reducing the risk of age-related macular disease and other ophthalmic conditions.
results_summary: The study found that high concentrations of lutein and zeaxanthin decrease the risk of developing age-related macular disease, highlighting their potential protective effects against oxidative stress-related eye conditions.
population_specificity: Older adults at risk of age-related eye diseases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of a micronutrient supplement containing lutein on the natural progression of Alzheimer's disease, focusing on cognitive and behavioral outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that supplementation with lutein (as part of a combined micronutrient regimen) significantly increased blood and skin carotenoid levels and improved memory and mood in Alzheimer's patients compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Patients with mild-moderate Alzheimer's disease.
effective_dosage: 10 mg lutein daily (as part of a 22 mg carotenoid blend).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review methods for analyzing macular carotenoids (including lutein) and their association with reducing age-related macular degeneration (AMD) risk.
results_summary: The study found that oral supplementation with lutein and other macular carotenoids can significantly reduce AMD risk, and it reviewed various extraction, detection, and imaging methods for these compounds.
population_specificity: Human and animal models (mice, Japanese quails), as well as algae, bacteria, chicken egg yolks, and cultured cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential development of public health recommendations for bioactive food components, including lutein, and discuss frameworks for evaluating their efficacy and safety.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings about lutein's effects, only mentioning it as a case study for evaluating bioactive compounds.
population_specificity: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the preventive properties of lutein and other carotenoids against respiratory diseases, focusing on their mechanisms of action and therapeutic potential.
results_summary: Lutein showed beneficial effects against chronic lung diseases by activating the NRF2/HO-1 pathway and inhibiting inflammatory pathways like NF-кB, MAPK, JAK/STAT-3, and PI3K/AKT. Epidemiological studies also suggested that dietary intake of lutein lowers the risk of lung diseases.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro, in vivo, and epidemiological studies referenced)

study_goal: The abstract does not mention Lutein or its study.
results_summary: The abstract does not discuss Lutein or its effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (abstract mentions North Bornean seaweed species).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the relationship between macular pigment density (lutein, meso-zeaxanthin, and zeaxanthin) and cognitive functions in healthy individuals.
results_summary: Most observational studies correlated macular pigment optical density (MPOD) with cognitive function, while RCTs showed that increasing lutein and zeaxanthin intake improved cognitive functions like memory, processing speed, attention, and reasoning. Brain activity was inconsistently related to MPOD.
population_specificity: Healthy individuals with no age, sex, or race limitations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of lutein, among other antioxidants, in preventing or slowing the progression of age-related macular degeneration (AMD).
results_summary: The study found that lutein/zeaxanthin supplementation, along with other antioxidants, may be effective against AMD progression, particularly in reducing the risk of late AMD. The protective effects were noted in the context of dietary patterns rich in ω-3 fatty acids.
population_specificity: Individuals over 50 years of age, particularly those at risk for or with age-related macular degeneration.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore current carotenoid research trends, including Lutein, focusing on bioavailability, metabolism, and health effects such as eye and cardiovascular health, cognitive function, and gut microbiota interactions.
results_summary: The study found that Lutein was one of the most investigated carotenoids, with research corroborating previous findings on vision and cardiovascular health, while also exploring emerging areas like cognitive function and gut microbiota interactions, though these areas require further study.
population_specificity: Not specified (broad analysis of registered clinical trials)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary supplements of lutein (L) + zeaxanthin (Z) or L + Z + meso-zeaxanthin (MZ) improve cognitive function in adults.
results_summary: Most studies found that macular pigments (L + Z) in blood or macula positively correlated with cognitive performance, and higher macular pigment levels were linked to lower risk of mild cognitive impairments or Alzheimer's disease. Dietary supplements of L + Z or L + Z + MZ were associated with improved cognition in adults.
population_specificity: Adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combined supplementation of Lutein with omega-3 fatty acids and vitamin E improves cognitive performance in older adults.
results_summary: The study found that supplementation significantly improved working memory performance, with greater benefits observed under higher cognitive load. Increased carotenoid concentrations in tissue and blood were linked to improved memory performance.
population_specificity: Cognitively healthy individuals aged ≥65 years.
effective_dosage: 10 mg lutein daily, combined with other carotenoids, omega-3 fatty acids, and vitamin E.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify clinical factors associated with hyperthyroidism in women with complete hydatidiform mole (CHM) and assess post-evacuation thyroid function.
results_summary: The study found that uterine fundal height > 16 cm, theca lutein cysts >6 cm, and hCG >400,000 IU/L were associated with hyperthyroidism in CHM patients. Thyroid function normalized within 2-3 weeks post-evacuation.
population_specificity: Women with complete hydatidiform mole (CHM) attending a specialized Brazilian center (2002-2018).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of dietary intervention with lutein-rich fruits or vegetables on lutein status markers and visual outcomes.
results_summary: Serum lutein concentration increased by 37%, and the intervention significantly affected serum lutein+zeaxanthin concentration. Visual outcomes (MPOD and CT) were also measured, but specific results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: 29 healthy normolipemic subjects aged 45-65 years.
effective_dosage: 1.8 mg lutein/day from fruits (500 g/day of oranges, kiwi, avocados) or vegetables (180 g/day of green beans, pumpkin, sweet corn).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between adherence to the Mediterranean Diet and circulating dietary-related biomarkers, including lutein, in breast cancer survivors.
results_summary: The study found a positive correlation between adherence to the Mediterranean Diet and β-carotene levels, but specific results for lutein were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Eighty breast cancer survivors (mean age 54.9 ± 10.6) who had not received pharmacological or radiotherapy treatment for at least two months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of daily consumption of lutein/zeaxanthin and DHA-enriched eggs on macular pigment optical density (MPOD) and circulating xanthophyll and fatty acid concentrations in healthy participants.
results_summary: A slight but significant increase in MPOD was observed in all participants consuming two eggs daily for 4 months. Plasma and lipoprotein lutein, zeaxanthin, and DHA concentrations significantly increased, with greater enhancements in the enriched egg group, and a strong correlation was found between MPOD and lutein concentration in HDL.
population_specificity: Healthy volunteers
effective_dosage: Two eggs per day (standard or enriched with lutein/zeaxanthin and DHA)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the association between plasma nutrients, including α-carotene, and cognitive function in a population at risk for cognitive decline.
results_summary: The study found that high plasma α-carotene was associated with better global cognition, with participants in the highest tertile showing higher global cognition scores. No specific results for Lutein were mentioned.
population_specificity: Individuals at risk for cognitive decline with a suboptimal diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the overall effect of lutein on cognitive domains (complex attention, executive function, and memory) in adults using available placebo-controlled trials.
results_summary: The study assessed lutein's impact on cognition through meta-analysis but noted insufficient data to substantiate its effects on human cognition. The abstract does not provide specific outcome details.
population_specificity: Adult population

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether carotenoid supplementation (including lutein) improves night vision function and useful field of view (UFOV) in individuals with night vision difficulties.
results_summary: The study found that augmenting macular pigment optical density (MPOD) with carotenoid supplementation improved visual functions important for night driving and enhanced UFOV divided attention test scores while reducing composite crash risk scores.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals with difficulty in night vision.
effective_dosage: 14 mg zeaxanthin / 7 mg lutein-based supplement (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the synergistic role of lutein, along with other micronutrients, in protecting membrane structure and function to prevent neurodegeneration and support brain health.
results_summary: The study found that lutein, in combination with other membrane-soluble and water-soluble micronutrients, operates in oxidation-reduction cycles to protect membrane function and prevent chronic inflammation, supporting brain health.
population_specificity: General aging population (not specified further).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether serum and macular levels of lutein and zeaxanthin (L/Z) were associated with central retinal arteriole and venule calibers in older women.
results_summary: Higher serum L/Z and macular pigment optical density (MPOD) were associated with larger central retinal vessel calibers, with stronger associations observed in women with stable MPOD over 15 years. The effects were statistically significant for venules and showed a trend for arterioles.
population_specificity: Older women participating in the Women's Health Initiative and Carotenoids in Age-Related Eye Disease Study 2 (CAREDS2).
study_duration: Follow-up over 15 years (from WHI baseline in 1994-1998 to CAREDS2 in 2016-2019).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the neuroprotective benefits of lutein and other macular carotenoids in the context of primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG).
results_summary: The abstract suggests that lutein may help mitigate oxidative stress and mitochondrial dysfunction in glaucoma, potentially reducing neurodegeneration, but specific results are not detailed.
population_specificity: Individuals with primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) or at risk for oxidative stress-related neurodegeneration.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the association between lutein intake and brain health in older adults, focusing on brain activities and structures measured via MRI and EEG.
results_summary: The study found that 10 mg lutein intake over 12 months positively impacted brain activities, resting-state connectivity, and gray matter volumes in healthy older adults. Cross-sectional studies also linked lutein to improved brain structure and neural efficiency during cognitive tasks.
population_specificity: Healthy older adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of medicinal products containing the original AREDS formulation at doses approved in Europe.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding Lutein's effects.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of carotenoids, including Lutein, on inflammatory parameters through a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that carotenoids significantly reduced C-reactive protein (CRP) levels, indicating anti-inflammatory effects. However, specific results for Lutein alone were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Not specified (meta-analysis of 26 trials with varied populations).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the clinical evidence on carotenoids, including Lutein, for skin protection against UV-induced damage and oxidative stress.
results_summary: Carotenoid supplementation, including Lutein, was found to enhance skin resistance against UVB-induced erythema and UVA-induced pigmentation while reducing oxidative stress markers like intercellular adhesion molecule 1 and matrix metalloproteinases. Recent studies suggest broader photoprotective benefits beyond erythema reduction.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of clinical studies over five decades)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether prenatal maternal supplementation with lutein and zeaxanthin could counteract maternal carotenoid depletion during pregnancy and improve biomarkers of carotenoid status in both mothers and infants.
results_summary: The study is ongoing, so no results regarding lutein's effects are reported in the abstract.
population_specificity: Pregnant women and their infants.
effective_dosage: 10 mg lutein and 2 mg zeaxanthin daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the bioactivity and biological effects of xanthophylls, including lutein, focusing on their antioxidant, anti-tumor, and anti-inflammatory properties.
results_summary: The study highlights lutein's antioxidant properties, which help protect molecules from oxidative stress by neutralizing singlet oxygen damage. It also notes lutein's potential anti-tumor and anti-inflammatory activities due to its chemical structure rich in double bonds.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of clinical studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of vaginal progesterone gel combined with oral dydrogesterone versus intramuscular progesterone for luteal support in hormone replacement therapy-frozen embryo transfer (HRT-FET) cycles.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in pregnancy or neonatal outcomes between the two progesterone protocols, suggesting similar efficacy. Vaginal progesterone combined with oral dydrogesterone was deemed a viable alternative due to comparable safety and convenience.
population_specificity: Women undergoing HRT-FET cycles (208 cycles in the vaginal + oral group, 624 cycles in the intramuscular group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the biological functions and health benefits of astaxanthin, comparing its antioxidant and anti-inflammatory activity to related compounds like lutein.
results_summary: The abstract highlights astaxanthin's superior antioxidant capacity compared to lutein and other carotenoids, with potential benefits for neuroprotection, cardiovascular health, and eye diseases, but does not provide specific results for lutein.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing studies)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether egg consumption, as a dietary source of lutein and zeaxanthin, influences macular pigment optical density (MPOD) and serum lutein levels.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that egg consumption significantly increased MPOD and serum lutein levels, suggesting potential benefits for reducing AMD progression. Subgroup analyses indicated stronger effects in parallel-designed studies and healthy populations.
population_specificity: 296 participants across five randomized clinical trials, including healthy individuals and potentially those at risk for AMD (specifics not detailed).
effective_dosage: Not specified (egg consumption frequency/quantity not detailed).
study_duration: Not specified (duration of intervention not detailed).

study_goal: The abstract does not explicitly state the researchers' goal regarding Lutein.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings about Lutein's effects.
population_specificity: Individuals aged 60 and older with age-related macular degeneration (AMD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of lutein supplementation, alongside other micronutrients and DHA, on maternal nutrient status and milk composition in lactating women.
results_summary: Supplementation increased maternal blood lutein by 4% and improved other nutrient biomarkers without significant adverse events. No notable safety concerns were reported for lutein.
population_specificity: Healthy lactating women in Germany (n=70).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of two nutritional supplements (Lumega-Z and PreserVision AREDS-2) on visual and ocular parameters in individuals with retinal drusen.
results_summary: The LM group showed statistically significant improvements in contrast sensitivity function (CSF) in both eyes at six months compared to the PV group, indicating greater and faster benefits in visual performance.
population_specificity: Individuals with fine retinal drusen (sub-clinical age-related macular degeneration) and ocular normal controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate lutein encapsulation and cellular uptake using nanoparticle delivery vehicles to enhance its bioavailability for potential oral cancer prevention.
results_summary: Nanoparticles produced via high-throughput EM-NP methods showed higher encapsulation efficiency (55%) and faster cellular uptake in premalignant oral epithelial cells compared to other delivery systems, suggesting P90G as a promising candidate for future lutein delivery research.
population_specificity: Premalignant oral epithelial cells (SCC83)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of 12 mg lutein administration over 16 weeks on macular pigment optical density (MPOD), contrast sensitivity, glare sensitivity, and serum lutein levels.
results_summary: The lutein group showed significantly improved MPOD, contrast sensitivity, and glare sensitivity at week 16, along with significantly increased serum lutein levels at weeks 8 and 16 compared to the placebo group. Continuous lutein administration enhanced visual clarity and protected against glare-induced visual function declines.
population_specificity: 59 healthy male and female adults aged 20-69 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a multimodal intervention combining exercise and a nutritional supplement containing Lutein could enhance physical fitness and cognitive performance in military personnel.
results_summary: The study found that the multimodal intervention, including Lutein, improved working memory, fluid intelligence reaction time, processing efficiency, heart rate, and lean muscle mass compared to exercise alone. The supplement was part of a broader formulation that showed additive benefits over placebo.
population_specificity: Active-duty Air Force Airmen (n=148)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate how different food matrix structures affect the bioavailability of fat-soluble micronutrients, including vitamin D.
results_summary: The study found that food structure significantly impacts triglyceride and vitamin D bioavailability, but specific results for Lutein were not mentioned.
population_specificity: 12 healthy subjects

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of lutein-enriched egg yolk on vascular function, specifically flow-mediated dilatation (FMD).
results_summary: The study found that lutein-enriched egg yolk did not have a significant positive effect on FMD. However, other egg derivatives showed some improvement in vascular function.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of Macumax (containing Lutein) in patients with early-stage dry-type age-related macular degeneration (AMD).
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding Lutein's effects, only stating that a 90-day study was conducted.
population_specificity: 40 patients aged 50 years or older with early-stage dry-type AMD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the relationship between carotenoid intake (including Lutein) and blood/tissue concentrations, as well as their health effects, to propose safe and desirable concentration ranges.
results_summary: The study found that carotenoid intake and blood/tissue concentrations are highly variable and influenced by factors like study type, dose, and individual differences. High plasma carotenoid concentrations (up to 7500 nmol/L) are achievable with supplementation, but higher doses show a plateauing effect.
population_specificity: General population, with considerations for age, sex, disease state, and genetic makeup.
effective_dosage: Not specified for Lutein alone; mentions supraphysiological doses for total carotenoids.

study_goal: The study aimed to examine the effect of pistachio nut consumption on overweight/obese adults, not specifically Lutein.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results related to Lutein.
population_specificity: Non-diabetic overweight/obese adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of lutein-rich vegetables on metabolic syndrome markers, particularly visceral fat and gene expression, in obese Japanese men.
results_summary: The study found that lutein-rich vegetable intake increased plasma carotenoid levels and reduced visceral fat, with gene expression changes observed in the low-carotenoid group. Waist circumference decreased significantly only in the high-lycopene, low-lutein group.
population_specificity: Middle-aged (40-65 years) obese Japanese men (BMI ≥ 25).
effective_dosage: Not specified (dietary groups categorized as high or low lutein).

study_goal: The abstract does not mention Lutein or its study.
results_summary: The abstract does not discuss Lutein or its effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (abstract focuses on GI cancer risk factors).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the effect of carotenoid intake, specifically lutein, on cognitive functions in humans through a systematic review of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: Lutein consumption showed selective improvement in visual episodic memory in young and middle-aged adults, while inhibition was observed in middle-aged and older adults. A dosage of 10 mg lutein per day for twelve months was associated with cognitive function improvement.
population_specificity: Healthy young, middle-aged, and older adults.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective effect of a botanical combination containing lutein ester, zeaxanthin, and extracts of blackcurrant, chrysanthemum, and goji berry on adults with eye fatigue.
results_summary: The formula improved eye fatigue symptoms, increased tear secretion, and enhanced macular pigment optical density without altering retinal structure. All three doses (6 mg, 10 mg, and 14 mg of lutein) showed significant benefits compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Adults with eye fatigue (360 participants).
effective_dosage: 6 mg, 10 mg, or 14 mg of lutein once daily (chewable tablets).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether co-ingestion of fermented milk with lutein-rich spinach enhances lutein bioavailability in humans.
results_summary: Consumption of spinach with fermented milk significantly increased plasma lutein levels across all fractions, whereas spinach alone did not show this effect. The study suggests fermented milk improves lutein absorption.
population_specificity: Human subjects (n=16 per study) and male rats (n=8 or 6 per group).
effective_dosage: Not specified for lutein; fermented milk co-ingested with spinach drink.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of lutein supplementation on macular pigment optical density (MPOD), visual acuity, and contrast sensitivity in patients with age-related macular degeneration (AMD).
results_summary: Lutein supplementation (10 or 20 mg/day) was associated with significant increases in MPOD, visual acuity, and contrast sensitivity, with higher doses and longer treatment durations yielding faster and greater improvements in MPOD.
population_specificity: Patients with age-related macular degeneration (AMD), totaling 920 eyes (855 with AMD) across nine randomized controlled trials.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the gene expression of sirtuins in human mural granulosa-lutein cells (hGL) from IVF patients across different infertility diagnostic groups and oocyte donors, focusing on associations with age and IVF parameters.
results_summary: The study found higher expression levels of SIRT1, SIRT2, and SIRT5 in patients ≥40 years old compared to younger groups and controls. SIRT2, SIRT5, and SIRT7 expression correlated with age, while SIRT3, SIRT5, SIRT6, and SIRT7 were elevated in poor responders, suggesting a link to cellular physiopathology in follicles.
population_specificity: Human mural granulosa-lutein cells (hGL) from IVF patients, including poor responders, endometriosis, polycystic ovarian syndrome, and oocyte donors (controls).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the pharmaco-pharmaceutical applications of xanthophylls, including lutein, focusing on their functionality, bioavailability, and therapeutic effects in various diseases.
results_summary: Lutein demonstrated neuroprotective effects and prevented the progression of age-related macular degeneration. It also showed promising effects on other ophthalmologic conditions like uveitis, retinitis pigmentosa, and cataracts.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of existing studies).
interactions: Mentioned potential interaction with beta-carotene, but no specifics provided.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the mechanistic pathways of lutein in the prevention of atherosclerosis and its effects on related risk factors.
results_summary: The review found positive effects of lutein on endothelial function, anti-inflammatory properties, and lipid profile, though further studies are needed on hyperglycemia, blood pressure, and coagulation.
population_specificity: In vitro, ex vivo, animal, and human studies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the neuroprotective activity of lutein and other carotenoids against Aβ aggregation in Alzheimer's disease using computational molecular docking analysis.
results_summary: The study found that lutein and other carotenoids exhibit strong anti-amyloidogenic properties by inhibiting Aβ aggregation through hydrogen bonding and van der Waals interactions, suggesting potential preventive benefits for Alzheimer's disease.
population_specificity: Not specified (computational study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supplementation with lutein and other macular xanthophylls could improve systemic antioxidant capacity, reduce inflammation, enhance neurotrophic factors like BDNF, and improve cognitive performance in young, healthy individuals.
results_summary: The study found that lutein supplementation significantly increased BDNF, antioxidant capacity, and macular pigment density while reducing IL-1β. Cognitive performance, including memory, attention, and processing speed, also improved significantly in the treatment groups.
population_specificity: Young, healthy adults aged 18-25 years.
effective_dosage: 13 mg/day or 27 mg/day total macular xanthophylls (lutein, zeaxanthin, and meso-zeaxanthin).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of novel food processing techniques (PEF, OH, HPP) versus conventional thermal treatment on carotenoid bioaccessibility and Caco-2 cell uptake, including lutein, in tomato and kale-based juices.
results_summary: The abstract mentions lutein was quantitated in juices and the micelle fraction, but specific results for lutein bioaccessibility or uptake are not detailed. PEF increased lycopene bioaccessibility in tomato juice, but lutein-specific outcomes are not reported.
population_specificity: In vitro (Caco-2 cells) and food matrices (tomato and kale-based juices).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether lutein supplementation (10 mg daily for 12 weeks) affects serum lutein levels, glycemic and lipid profiles, inflammatory factors, and body composition in adults with central obesity.
results_summary: The abstract does not report results, as the study appears to be a protocol for a future trial.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18-60 with central obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of lutein (combined with zeaxanthin) on cardiometabolic, inflammatory, and antioxidant parameters in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The study found no significant changes in cardiometabolic, inflammatory, or antioxidant parameters after 8 months of lutein and zeaxanthin supplementation compared to baseline.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women
effective_dosage: 6 mg lutein and 2 mg zeaxanthin per day

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the plasma status of lutein and other fat-soluble micronutrients in institutionalized elderly and evaluate the impact of strength training with or without supplementation on these levels.
results_summary: The study found no significant biological impact of six months of elastic band resistance training with or without protein-vitamin supplementation on the plasma status of lutein and other fat-soluble micronutrients. Plasma analyses were supported by intake data, but no specific changes in lutein levels were highlighted.
population_specificity: Institutionalized elderly individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of grape phytochemicals, including lutein, in regulating inflammatory responses and preventing inflammatory diseases.
results_summary: The study found that lutein, as part of grape phytochemicals, contributes to anti-inflammatory effects by modulating gut microbiota and reducing TNF-α production, with benefits observed in liver, lung, and arteriosclerosis sites.
population_specificity: Not specified (general inflammatory disease context, supported by animal studies and clinical trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of lutein and other macular carotenoids in enhancing visual performance, particularly contrast sensitivity.
results_summary: The study found that lutein, zeaxanthin, and meso-zeaxanthin improve visual performance, including contrast sensitivity, and recommends their supplementation for better clinical outcomes.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion, likely adults with visual performance concerns).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential link between antioxidant carotenoids like lutein and zeaxanthin and their role in reducing glaucoma risk.
results_summary: The study found inconsistent evidence linking dietary antioxidants to glaucoma risk but highlighted a possible association between macular pigment levels (including lutein) and glaucoma. Prospective studies are needed for clearer conclusions.
population_specificity: Individuals with or at risk for primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential benefits of carotenoids, including Lutein, in mitigating oxidative stress and inflammation in age-related ocular diseases.
results_summary: The study found that carotenoids and polyphenols, including Lutein, demonstrated antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties that could be beneficial for age-related ophthalmic diseases such as cataracts, glaucoma, diabetic retinopathy, and macular degeneration.
population_specificity: Individuals with or at risk of age-related ocular diseases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review lutein's properties, dietary sources, usual intake, efficacy in human health, and toxicity based on recent findings.
results_summary: Lutein shows beneficial effects on eye health, particularly in preventing age-related macular disease, and may improve cognitive function, reduce cancer risk, and enhance cardiovascular health. However, conflicting data exist on its efficacy and optimal dosage.
population_specificity: General human population, with focus on age-related macular disease and chronic conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify correlates of plasma carotenoid concentrations, including lutein, in men and women under controlled dietary interventions.
results_summary: The study found that plasma lutein concentrations were influenced by body weight, waist circumference, and plasma lipid levels, with women showing higher concentrations despite lower dietary intake. Adjusting for HDL-cholesterol eliminated sex differences in plasma carotenoid levels.
population_specificity: Men (n=155) and women (n=110) enrolled in six fully controlled dietary interventions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify the status of lutein in Nigerian maternal-infant pairs at delivery and compare these levels to a developed nation cohort.
results_summary: The study measured concentrations of lutein + zeaxanthin in maternal and cord blood samples but did not report specific outcomes or effects related to lutein's efficacy or safety.
population_specificity: 99 Nigerian mother-infant pairs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the association between dietary or supplemental vitamin A derivatives (including β-carotene) and breast cancer survival outcomes.
results_summary: The study found a significant inverse association between prediagnosis dietary β-carotene intake and improved overall survival in breast cancer patients, but no significant association with other vitamin A derivatives.
population_specificity: Women with breast cancer (19,450 cases across 10 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the genetic factors influencing the interindividual variability of Lutein bioavailability from tomatoes.
results_summary: The study found that Lutein bioavailability varies significantly among individuals, with genetic variants (SNPs) in several genes, including ELOVL2, contributing to this variability. The effects of individual genetic variants were small, but their combined influence could explain a notable fraction of the variability.
population_specificity: General population (interindividual variability focus)

study_goal: The researchers reviewed the therapeutic potentials, biological activities, and health effects of Astaxanthin (AST), focusing on its pharmacological mechanisms in treating nervous system diseases.
results_summary: The abstract highlights AST's broad protective effects against diseases, excellent safety and tolerability, and proposes a novel hypothesis for its mechanism in neuropathic pain following spinal cord injury.
population_specificity: Not specified (review article, not a clinical study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary intake of lutein (and other vitamins/carotenoids) was associated with a reduced risk of age-related cataract (ARC).
results_summary: The study found that higher lutein or zeaxanthin intake was significantly associated with a reduced risk of ARC in cohort studies (RR: 0.81; 95% CI: 0.75, 0.89; P < 0.001), with a 26% risk reduction per 10-mg/d increase. RCTs did not specifically assess lutein's efficacy.
population_specificity: General population (participants in cohort studies and RCTs related to ARC risk).
effective_dosage: 10-mg/d increase in lutein or zeaxanthin intake (dose-response analysis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effects of carotenoids, particularly lutein-zeaxanthin, on human health, focusing on their potential benefits for cardiovascular disease, cancer, and eye disease.
results_summary: The study suggests that carotenoid consumption, including lutein, is associated with a lower risk of cardiovascular disease, cancer, and eye disease, based on clinical studies.
population_specificity: General human population (not specified further).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether higher serum carotenoid levels, including Lutein, are associated with reduced kidney function decline in adults with preserved kidney function.
results_summary: Higher serum carotenoid levels (including Lutein) were significantly associated with lower odds of rapid kidney function decline, suggesting a protective effect. No association was found for other nutrients like tocopherols, ascorbic acid, or lycopene.
population_specificity: 2,152 men and women with preserved kidney function (cystatin-C-based eGFR > 60 mL/minute/1.73 m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential of bioactive lipids, including carotenoids like Lutein, in slowing the progression of mild cognitive impairment (MCI) to Alzheimer's disease (AD).
results_summary: The study suggests that polar lipids, omega-3 fatty acids, and carotenoids (including Lutein) may work additively or synergistically to modify risk factors for MCI conversion to AD, warranting further large-scale trials.
population_specificity: Individuals with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) at risk of progressing to Alzheimer's disease (AD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the functional and histopathological outcomes of macular peeling using different dyes, including lutein, to assess its impact on retinal tissue stress and recovery.
results_summary: Lutein (2%) combined with other dyes resulted in significantly better visual acuity and macular sensitivity at 1 and 3 months post-surgery, with lower GFAP and NF expression, suggesting reduced iatrogenic stress and faster functional recovery. No significant difference was observed after 6 months.
population_specificity: 45 patients with idiopathic epiretinal membrane (ERM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the health benefits of lutein, particularly its role in reducing the progression of age-related macular eye disease and cataracts, as well as its potential effects on cognitive function, cardiovascular health, and cancer prevention.
results_summary: The study found that lutein has strengthening evidence for reducing the progression of age-related macular eye disease and cataracts, with additional potential benefits for cognitive function, cardiovascular health, and cancer prevention, though large population-based supplementation studies have produced mixed results for some carotenoids.
population_specificity: General population (not specified further)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential benefits of lutein and zeaxanthin supplements for preserving or restoring vision in dry AMD and STGD, using short-term measures of retinal function.
results_summary: The study identified lutein as a promising research topic but noted a lack of high-quality studies with sufficient duration to assess its efficacy definitively. Future research was suggested to explore its value further.
population_specificity: People with dry age-related macular degeneration (AMD) or Stargardt disease (STGD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review pharmaceutical drugs for retinitis pigmentosa (RP), focusing on drug discovery, development, and clinical translation.
results_summary: The abstract does not mention Lutein or its effects; it broadly discusses therapeutic advancements for RP, including gene therapy, pharmacotherapy, and other treatments.
population_specificity: Patients with retinitis pigmentosa (RP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of supplemental xanthophyll carotenoids (including lutein) combined with omega-3 fatty acids on disease progression in Alzheimer's patients.
results_summary: The study found that a combination of xanthophyll carotenoids (including lutein) and fish oil led to significantly greater increases in blood xanthophyll levels and slower AD progression compared to carotenoids alone, with reported functional benefits in memory, sight, and mood.
population_specificity: Patients with Alzheimer's disease (mild, moderate, and severe) and a control group free of AD.
effective_dosage: Lutein 10 mg/day (as part of a 10:10:2 mg/day lutein:meso-zeaxanthin:zeaxanthin formulation).
study_duration: 18 months for AD patients, 6 months for the control group.

study_goal: The abstract does not mention Lutein or its effects.
results_summary: The abstract does not discuss Lutein or its effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (abstract focuses on cerebral ischemia-reperfusion injury mechanisms).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare serum levels of lutein and other dietary antioxidants between Alzheimer's disease patients and cognitively intact controls to assess potential neuroprotective effects.
results_summary: The study found that Alzheimer's disease patients had significantly lower plasma levels of lutein compared to controls, suggesting reduced systemic availability of this antioxidant in AD. However, considerable heterogeneity across studies warrants caution in interpreting these findings.
population_specificity: Patients with Alzheimer's disease and cognitively intact controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether consumption of biofortified maize, which contains elevated carotenoids including lutein, impacts serum lutein concentrations in children.
results_summary: The study found no significant impact on serum lutein concentrations despite increases in other carotenoids like β-carotene, α-carotene, β-cryptoxanthin, and zeaxanthin.
population_specificity: Rural Zambian children (n=679)
effective_dosage: Not specified (daily consumption of biofortified maize providing upwards of 15 μg β-carotene per g dry weight)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether supplementation with lutein (L), zeaxanthin (Z), and meso-zeaxanthin (MZ) could improve memory, executive function, and verbal fluency in healthy individuals with low macular pigment levels.
results_summary: The study found that 12-month supplementation with L, Z, and MZ significantly improved memory performance compared to placebo, with reductions in errors on memory tasks positively correlated with increases in macular pigment volume and serum carotenoid concentrations.
population_specificity: Healthy individuals with low macular pigment levels (mean age 45.42±12.40; 51.6% male).
effective_dosage: 10 mg L, 10 mg MZ, and 2 mg Z daily.
